results.title: Responsibility: what limits? ('Those Callaways')
results.brief_description: Excerpt from the 1964 film “Those Calloways”. Presents a story about a man whose private dream of establishing a bird sanctuary interferes with commercial development of a hunting resort. Shows the conflict that arises when he takes the law into his own hands.

results.title: Manioc bread
results.creator_credit: Hermann Schlenker, Julien Bryan and International Film Foundation
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Indians of the Orinoco: the Makiritare”.
Shows Makiritare women making bread from manioc roots. First they remove the poison by squeezing the shredded roots in enormous basket-tubes. From the flour they make yucca or cassava bread, a dietary staple. The bread is toasted on a flat piece of iron and tossed onto a roof to dry. Suitable for upper primary and lower secondary levels.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Hermann Schlenker, Julien Bryan and International Film Foundation

results.title: Jungle farming
results.creator_credit: Hermann Schlenker and International Film Foundation
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Indians of the Orinoco: the Makiritare”.
Describes the cooperative work involved in jungle farming of the Makiritare Indians. Explains that, after the men use the slash and burn technique to clear the jungle away, the women simultaneously harvest and plant manioc roots, pineapples, chillipeppers, bananas and plantations. Living near the equator they can farm all the year round. Suitable for upper primary and lower secondary levels.

results.title: Village life
results.creator_credit: Hermann Schlenker, Julien Bryan and International Film Foundation
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Indians of the Orinoco: the Makiritare”.
Introduces the variety of activities in the Makiritare Indian village of Kononama (South America). Women spin cotton, look after babies and chickens, and bathe in the river, while the children draw, wrestle and throw spears. Men weave baskets from sisal for squeezing the poison out of manloc roots and make jewellery for a dance.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Hermann Schlenker, Julien Bryan and International Film Foundation

results.title: Food gathering
results.creator_credit: Hermann Schlenker and International Film Foundation
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Indians of the Orinoco: the Makiritare”.
Records how the Waika and Makiritare Indians of South America gather some of their food from the jungle. Includes catching of snakes, fish and worms and their preparation for eating and the collection of leaves which are beaten and mashed and used ingeniously to catch fish. Suitable for middle and upper primary and lower secondary levels.

results.title: Basic film language
results.creator_credit: Ivan Gaal, Ross Campbell and Victoria. Audio-Visual Education Centre
results.brief_description: Shows the basic language of camera work in a clear and linear style within the context of a planned film. In two parts; “The Encounter”, the first part, is silent and shows Bob Thornycroft and Joe Bolza mime an encounter between death and a grave digger. “The Elements in Detail”, the second part, shows all the film techniques used being carefully analysed as the action is repeated and also analyses different shots that can be used by students.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Ivan Gaal, Ross Campbell and Victoria. Audio-Visual Education Centre

results.title: Carcassonne: a French fortress = Carcassonne, fortifications francaises
results.creator_credit: Ernest Kleinberg, Ernest Kleinberg Films and Oxford Films (U.S.)
results.brief_description: A French language teaching film. Presents a visual tour through Carcassonne, the finest example of a fortified medieval city. Shows how the past influences the lives of the townspeople and includes scenes of shops, schools and farms as well as a brief sequence of a French family. Suitable for secondary school level.

results.title: Who is Vasco Mutwa?
results.creator_credit: Alex Learmont, Alex Learmont Productions and Great Britain. Ministry of Information
results.brief_description: This film is used to balance any bias in “Last Grave at Dimbaza” and also to present the official South African view. It shows blacks as professionals, and stresses the cultural variations between African groups. About the Bantu nations of South Africa.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Alex Learmont, Alex Learmont Productions and Great Britain. Ministry of Information

results.title: Last grave at Dimbaza
results.brief_description: This film is a strident criticism of the operation of apartheid, and investigates most areas of life in South Africa, including the Bantustans. The film produces a visual catalogue of the disparity of conditions within life styles, between the blacks and the whites. (Awards: Mannheim-Heidelberg; Melbourne)

results.title: White man's country
results.creator_credit: Anthony Howarth, David Kopp, Anthony-David Productions and Films Incorporated
results.brief_description: This is a well-documented film which deals with British Colonialism in Kenya from an African viewpoint. This film works as an expose of colonialists, and can be used to study them, or as part of an African history course.
